Heuristic evaluation: Usability experts judge whether each element of a user interface follows established usability principles

Nielsenâ€™s Heuristics.Definition: A set of heuristics for determining usability of a system

Heuristics.Visibility of system status: The system should always keep users informed about what is going on
Heuristics.Recognition rather than recall: Minimize the user's memory load by making objects, actions, and options visible
Heuristics.Consistency and standards: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing
Heuristics.Aesthetic and minimalist design: Dialogues should not contain information which is irrelevant or rarely needed
Heuristics.Match the real world: The system should speak the user's language, with words, phrases and concepts familiar to the user
Heuristics.User control: Users often choose system functions by mistake and will need a clearly marked 'emergency exit' to leave the unwanted state
Heuristics.Flexibility and efficiency of use: Accelerators may speed up the interaction for the expert user such that the system can cater to both inexperienced and experienced users
Heuristics.Error prevention: Even better than good error messages is a careful design which prevents a problem from occurring in the first place
Heuristics.Helpful errors: Error messages should precisely indicate the problem, and constructively suggest a solution
Heuristics.Help and documentation: It may be necessary to provide help and documentation. Any such information should be easy to search and list concrete steps to be carried out
